etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in John Westwood (1805–1893), entomologist and palaeographer. From pseudo- + tetramerous, after scientific Latin Pseudotetramera, former division name

definitions: Apparently but not actually tetramerous; (Entomology) designating tarsi with five segments which appear as four, the fourth segment being very small and hidden between the lobes of the third; (of a beetle) having such tarsi (obsolete, rare).

notes.text: In Westwood's system the coleopteran division Pseudotetramera was equivalent to the current superfamilies Chrysomeloidea and Curculionoidea.
